chapter.title: Data Input

section.title: Introduction
section.para: Data to be plotted can be presented to Magics in a number of ways, depending on its type: contour fields, wind fields, observations, symbols, axes, graphs and images.

A contour field can be presented as either a rectangular array of grid point values or in GRIB code format. GRIB code itself can be presented as either an external file, or as a one dimensional data array.

A wind field can be presented in GRIB code format or as a pair of rectangular arrays of grid point values, or as a single rectangular array of wind speed values (when plotting isotachs). The pair of rectangular arrays can contain U and V velocity components, vorticity and divergence components or speed and direction components of the wind. GRIB code can be presented as either an external file, or as a pair of one dimensional data arrays. See Wind and Contour ARRAY Input and GRIB Code Input for full details on data input for contouring and wind plotting.
Observation data must presented as an input file containing observations in WMO standard BUFR code. See OBSERVATION Data Input.

Data for symbol plotting are presented in arrays, which should all have the same number of elements. Two arrays are used to pass the position information. There are four different types of symbol input data: markers, numbers, text and wind. NUMBER input data are passed as an real array, TEXT input data consists of text strings. MARKER input data consists of indices to Magics markers and wind input data consists of two arrays containing wind direction and speed respectively. Symbols can be plotted in INDIVIDUAL or TABLE mode. See SYMBOL Plotting Data Input
Typically, graph data are presented in two one-dimensional arrays, where one holds the X-axis values and the other holds the Y-axis values. See GRAPH Data Input
Satellite Image data must be presented in GRIB code.

Before presenting data to Magics, the users should firstly decide on the type of data and the method by which they wish to present it. The Diagrams with the Magics parameter charts in this chapter should help.

When passing fields in GRIB code format, the necessary Magics INPUT parameters are automatically given appropriate values to ensure that a reasonable plot is obtained. When passing fields in array format, the user should select the appropriate values for the Magics INPUT parameters.

Although the use of GRIB input is essentially easier than the use of array input, the description of GRIB input in this chapter occurs after that of array input. This is because the array input description explains the function of those parameters that are set automatically when using GRIB input.

A contouring plot requires a single data field, whereas a wind plot requires two data fields for its full specification. The two fields can be U and V components or speed and direction components or vorticity and divergence components. Vorticity and divergence components can only be passed when using GRIB code data input. If isotachs are being plotted, then the field may be specified by the wind speed component only.
section.important: Magics++ Magics++ can not handle fields in spherical-harmonic representation. The user has to provide the data on a Gaussian or regular grid. This has the advantage that expensive interpolations are not performed when plotting data but at the time of retrieval. Most data users will handle are either in Gaussian or regular grid.

section.title: Organization of the Input Field
section.para: If the field is passed in array form, the user needs to describe how the array is to be mapped onto the subplot or geographical area which the array covers.
The input field organization is controlled by the parameter INPUT_FIELD_ORGANIZATION which can have two values: 'REGULAR' or 'GAUSSIAN', the default value being 'REGULAR'.

For a regular field, the default values for the parameters concerning array organization are set for a global latitude/ longitude field with 1.5 degrees resolution in both directions, going from 90.0 degrees north to 90.0 degrees south in latitude and from 0.0 degrees to 358.5 degrees in longitude.

For a gaussian field, the default values for the parameters concerning array organization are set for a global latitude/ longitude field with 1.125 degrees resolution in longitude and 1.1213 degrees in latitude, going from 89.142 degrees north to 89.142 degrees south in latitude and from 0.0 degrees to 358.875 degrees in longitude. (This conforms to a ECMWF T106 model post processed surface field).
section.important: Magics++ With Magics++, the concept of a 'FITTED' matrix no longer exists. The correct approach is to plot in a CARTESIAN projection and set INPUT_FIELD_INITIAL_X, INPUT_FIELD_FINAL_X, INPUT_FIELD_INITIAL_Y and INPUT_FIELD_FINAL_Y.

section.title: REGULAR Spaced Latitude/Longitude Grid
section.para: When INPUT_FIELD_ORGANIZATION is set to 'REGULAR' the field is assumed to be on a regular latitude/longitude grid.

Magics will perform the contouring in this grid and then plot the result according to the subpage mapping parameters, i.e. the field can either be global or a subpart of the field. Since the contouring is performed in the original grid it is ensured that all field values are taken into account when the isolines are generated. When using this method, a full specification of the input array is required:

listitem.para: The longitude and latitude position of the first element, (1,1), in the array may be set with the parameters:
The default values are 0.0 and 90.0, respectively.
The step lengths between positions of array elements in longitude and latitude directions are set by using the parameters:
Positive values indicate for longitudes that the positions go from west to east and for latitudes from south to north. Negative values are used to indicate opposite directions.
The default values are 1.5 for INPUT_FIELD_LONGITUDE_STEP and -1.5 for INPUT_FIELD_LATITUDE_STEP.

By default the first index of the array refers to longitude positions and the second index refers to latitudes. If these are interchanged, INPUT_FIELD_PRIMARY_INDEX should be set to 'LATITUDE'. Default is 'LONGITUDE'.
The following is a full list of the default values for describing the default input field with a regular grid.
listitem.programlisting: INPUT_FIELD_INITIAL_LATITUDE 90.0 INPUT_FIELD_INITIAL_LONGITUDE 0.0 INPUT_FIELD_LONGITUDE_STEP 1.5 INPUT_FIELD_LATITUDE_STEP -1.5 INPUT_FIELD_PRIMARY_INDEX LONGITUDE
listitem.para: In the default situation, the contouring or wind field array(s) passed to Magics via PSET2R should have dimensions of 240 in the direction of the first index and 121 in the direction of the second index.

section.title: GAUSSIAN Grid
section.para: When INPUT_FIELD_ORGANIZATION is set to 'GAUSSIAN', Magics will accept fields on a gaussian grid, even though the field is not regularly spaced.

The distance between grid points for gaussian grid fields is regular in the longitude direction but irregular in the latitude direction. However the variance in the grid distance along the irregularly spaced line is small enough that it may be regarded as regular and Magics makes this assumption.
Users should set INPUT_FIELD_LATITUDE_STEP to the average value of the latitude grid interval, which should be calculated as accurately as possible.
The following is a full list of the default values for the parameters describing an input field with a gaussian grid. (i.e. an ECMWF T106 model post processed surface field).
section.programlisting: INPUT_FIELD_INITIAL_LATITUDE 89.142 INPUT_FIELD_INITIAL_LONGITUDE 0.0 INPUT_FIELD_LONGITUDE_STEP 1.125 INPUT_FIELD_LATITUDE_STEP 1.1213 INPUT_FIELD_PRIMARY_INDEX LONGITUDE
section.para: In the default situation, the contouring or wind field array(s) passed to Magics via PSET2R should have dimensions of 320 in the direction of the first index and 160 in the direction of the second index.

section.title: Data Suppression
section.para: By using the suppress parameters INPUT_FIELD_SUPPRESS_ABOVE and INPUT_FIELD_SUPPRESS_BELOW, users may suppress data values beyond a certain value in a contouring or wind field. This may be necessary when the user is aware that some of his data are invalid above or below a certain value.
In the case of a contouring field, suppression means that the data values outside the permitted range are eliminated before any calculation of contour levels or gradient estimation takes place.

For example, by setting INPUT_FIELD_SUPPRESS_ABOVE to 1.0E20 , all contour levels above 1.0E20 would be suppressed. Please note that the suppress parameters should only be used to suppress invalid data. If used wrongly, the data plotted may not be accurate, particularly contour maxima/minima values.

section.title: GRIB Code Input
section.para: To facilitate the plotting of GRIB code fields, there is an interface that enables users to plot GRIB code with a minimum of programming effort. The action routine is called PGRIB.
Magics uses ECMWF's GRIB_API for the decoding of GRIB files. See GRIB_API for more details.
Note that the GRIB_API supports the updating of definition files without the need for a new release of the library. This is enabled through setting the environment variable
to the path where the new definition files reside.
See for a list of all the available parameters for accessing GRIB data.

section.title: Pseudo Action Routine PGRIB
section.para: The pseudo action routine PGRIB allows the automatic processing of GRIB code data. Users may call PGRIB to decode GRIB code data and, if required, to set the appropriate Magics input field, contour, wind, image and text parameters. PGRIB can deal with GRIB code on regular and Gaussian grids. It can also deal with GRIB coded polar stereographic data and with stretched/rotated GRIB data.

Basically, PGRIB will set up Magics parameters for plotting one meteorological field each time it is called. This field could be a wind field, which requires two input GRIB fields, normally U and V. The user will maintain the responsibility for setting up the page layout and mapping parameters as well as calling the action routines to perform the plotting, i.e. PCONT, PWIND, PIMAGE and PTEXT.
There are some Magics parameters associated with PGRIB that should be set before PGRIB is called. These parameters are explained later as are all the functions of PGRIB.

The format for calling pseudo action routine PGRIB is CALL PGRIB, with no arguments. It is necessary to call PGRIB before any action routine that requires the decoded data. After calling PGRIB and before calling an action routine, the user may set or reset any of the contouring, text, image or wind parameters, if required.
GRIB code may be passed to Magics as an input file or in a one dimensional array.

section.title: Functions of PGRIB
section.para: Depending on the user's requirements, PGRIB can perform some or all of the following functions:

listitem.para: Scale the meteorological fields, i.e. convert fields to standard units for plotting purposes, e.g. convert temperature fields from Kelvin to Celsius. The user may request, by setting a Magics parameter, that the fields should not be scaled. The standard units used by PGRIB can be found in the section on GRIB Table 2.

Build Magics text blocks to describe the data field. This text will include such information as time/date and type of field. Users may reset Magics text parameters after calling PGRIB and before calling action routines.

If the map required is not a global map, PGRIB can extract a subarea from the input field so that it covers almost exactly the geographic area required to be plotted. This helps reduce memory when contouring.

chapter.section:
Observation Data Input
This section needs to be thoroughly reviewed!
Data for observation plotting may be presented to Magics in the form of an input BUFR file or in an array.
The parameter OBS_INPUT_TYPE may be set to inform Magics of the data input type. It should be set to 'ARRAY' if the input data is in an array. The default value is 'FILE'.
An array may be used if only one observation is to be plotted, in which case the parameter OBS_INPUT_FIELD should be set using PSET2R.
CALL PSET1C ('OBS_INPUT_TYPE', 'ARRAY') CALL PSET1I ('OBS_INPUT_FIELD', IFIELD, N)
where IFIELD is an integer array of dimension N.
For passing more than one observation, an input file should be used, which can contain any number of observations of varying observation types and code types.
In this case, the parameter OBS_INPUT_FILE_UNIT should be set using PSETI, for example: CALL PSETI ('OBS_INPUT_FILE_UNIT', 2)
informs Magics that data for observation plotting is on file unit 2.

section.title: BUFR Tables
section.para: To enable the decoding of observations coded in BUFR, it is necessary to have tables which describe the contents of the BUFR code, e.g. the names and units of parameters, reference values and scale factors. The "parameters", as understood in the BUFR context, include not just the meteorological variables, but also the location of the observation, block/station number, instrumentation etc. Each parameter is described by a descriptor, which is an integer number that uniquely identifies the parameter, e.g. Temperature, Pressure, latitude/longitude, block number. These BUFR tables are stored at an address defined by an environment variable (which is made known to Magics installers at the various sites). The tables are then used in the BUFR decoding part of Magics and their use is transparent to the user. There are standard descriptor numbers for each of the "parameters". It is possible to use local descriptor numbers instead of the standard ones and these local descriptors would be described in the BUFR tables.
The EMOSLIB library is used for the handling of BUFR data. It is possible to specify a path to a different set of tables by setting the the environment variable
to the path where the tables reside. An example value for this variable would be: /home/ma/emos/tables/bufr/linux/000240.

section.title: BUFR Parameter Lists
section.para: To make it possible for Magics to be able to plot observations from BUFR code from varying originating centres, which may or may not use local descriptor numbers, it is necessary for Magics to be able to identify the descriptor numbers of the meteorological variables and those "parameters" that describe the position and time of the observation. To enable this for each originating centre, there are external files called BUFR Parameter Lists, where each file consists of a list of descriptors for the meteorological variables and the position and time "parameters". For each originating centre, these descriptor numbers should match those in the BUFR Tables described above.

There are two BUFR Parameter Lists for each originating centre, one for surface observations and one for upper air. Each list consists of entry lines, one entry line per meteorological variable or "parameter". An entry line consists of a descriptor number followed by an ampersand(&) and then, optionally, text to describe the variable.

para.token: descriptor & text describing the meteorological variable

section.para: For example, the first three lines of the upper air BUFR Parameter List should be as follows:
section.programlisting: 11001 & WIND DIRECTION 11002 & WIND SPEED 10195 & HEIGHT in mtrs
section.para: The position of the line in the list, not the text, is what actually defines the meteorological variable, e.g. the first entry line in the upper air BUFR Parameter Table is always the entry for Wind Direction, the second Wind Speed and the third Height. It is necessary to include each entry line in the file, even if they are not to be used. Complete lists for upper air and surface are given below.

section.title: Accessing BUFR Parameter Lists
section.para: There are two modes of accessing the BUFR Parameter Lists in Magics. By default, the lists are stored at an address path controlled by an environment variable, which is made known to installers at the various sites. The other mode of access is by setting a Magics parameter, BUFR_PARAM_TABLE_ADDRESS_PATH, to the address path of the tables. This means that users can then force Magics to use their own lists. Each upper air list name should have the format bufrtab_ua_nn (surface lists should have the format bufrtab_surf_nn ) where nn is the number of the originating Centre of the BUFR data, e.g. 98 for ECMWF, 85 for France.

section.title: Surface BUFR Parameter List
section.para: The ECMWF BUFR Parameter List for surface data, bufrtab_surf_98 is as follows (38 lines):
section.programlisting: 11011 & WIND DIRECTION at 10 m 11012 & WIND SPEED at 10m 20001 & HORIZONTAL VISIBILITY 20003 & PRESENT WEATHER 12004 & TEMPERATURE at 2m 20012 & MEDIUM CLOUD 20012 & HIGH CLOUD 10051 & MSL PRESSURE 10063 & PRESSURE TENDENCY CHARACTERISTIC (a) 10061 & PRESSURE TENDENCY AMOUNT (pp) 20004 & PAST WEATHER (1) 20005 & PAST WEATHER (2) 20011 & CLOUD AMOUNT (nh) 20013 & HEIGHT OF CLOUD BASE (h) 20012 & LOW CLOUD 12006 & DEWPOINT at 2m 22042 & SEA TEMPERATURE 1012 & SHIP'S DIRECTION 1013 & SHIP'S SPEED 20010 & TOTAL CLOUD 22002 & DIRECTION OF WIND WAVES 22012 & PERIOD OF WIND WAVES 22022 & HEIGHT OF WIND WAVES 22003 & DIRECTION OF SWELL WAVES 22013 & PERIOD OF SWELL WAVES 22023 & HEIGHT OF SWELL WAVES 22001 & DIRECTION OF WAVES 22011 & PERIOD OF WAVES 20021 & HEIGHT OF WAVES 4004 & HOUR 4005 & MINUTE 5001 & LATITUDE (HIGH ACCURACY) 5002 & LATITUDE (COARSE ACCURACY) 6001 & LONGITUDE (HGIH ACCURACY) 6002 & LONGITUDE (COARSE ACCURACY) 7001 & HEIGHT OF STATION in mtrs 7061 & DEPTH BELOW LAND SURFACE 12030 & SOIL TEMPERATURES
section.para: To make local surface BUFR Parameter Lists, it is only necessary to copy the above ECMWF surface list to a new list (with an appropriate name) and change the descriptor numbers to the ones to be used locally. It is important that all the above lines are included in each list, even if they are not to be used in plotting.
The position and time "parameters" are only given in the surface list.

section.title: ODB Data Input
section.para: With Magics++, Magics has the facility to import data from an ODB database using the action routine PODB and its associated parameters. A portion of FORTRAN code will show the basic usage and a discussion will follow.
section.programlisting:
CALL PSETC('odb_database', + 'odb://server/dir/subdir/database_file')
CALL PSETC ('odb_query', + 'SELECT lat, lon, obsvalue + FROM hdr, body + WHERE varno=$t2m AND obsvalue IS NOT null')
CALL PSETC ('odb_latitude', 'lat@hdr') CALL PSETC ('odb_longitude', 'lon@hdr') CALL PSETC ('odb_observation', 'obsvalue@body') CALL PSETI ('odb_nb_rows', 200000) CALL PODB
section.para: The first thing is to set the path to the database using the parameter ODB_DATABASE. An SQL query to retrieve the data is set in the parameter ODB_QUERY. Parameters ODB_LATITUDE, ODB_LONGITUDE and ODB_OBSERVATION are used to identify the columns containing the latitude, longitude and observation values in the data; also available is the parameter ODB_LEVEL.
For curve plotting, the parameters ODB_X and ODB_Y can be set to the names of the columns to be used for the x- and y-coordinates.
The start row and the maximum number of rows to retrieve can be set using the parameters ODB_STARTING_ROW and ODB_NB_ROWS respectively.

Finally, the action routine PODB is called without any parameters. The resulting data may be plotting using the symbol plotting routines
or the curve plotting routines(see ???).
Note that the automatic title that Magics++ produces for data retrieved from the ODB data is the query itself.

section.title: NetCDF Data Input
section.para: Magics++ is capable of reading NetCDF data files. A portion of FORTRAN code will show the basic usage and a discussion will follow.
section.programlisting: CALL PSETC ('NETCDF_FILENAME', 'data/rh850.nc') CALL PSETC ('NETCDF_FIELD_VARIABLE_NAME', 'r') CALL PSETC ('NETCDF_LATITUDE_VARIABLE_NAME', 'latitude') CALL PSETC ('NETCDF_LONGITUDE_VARIABLE_NAME', 'longitude') CALL PSETR ('NETCDF_FIELD_SCALING_FACTOR', 1.0) CALL PSETR ('NETCDF_FIELD_ADD_OFFSET', 0.0) CALL PNETCDF
section.para: The path to the file to be read is set via NETCDF_FILENAME. The variables in the NetCDF file to be used as latitude, longitude and value are specified using the parameters NETCDF_LATITUDE_VARIABLE_NAME, NETCDF_LONGITUDE_VARIABLE_NAME, and NETCDF_FIELD_VARIABLE_NAME respectively. The resultant data values can be multiplied by setting NETCDF_FIELD_SCALING_FACTOR to a value other than 1.0, and a constant added to each value via the parameter NETCDF_FIELD_ADD_OFFSET.

para.remark: Parameters netcdf_dimension_setting, netcdf_x_variable_name, netcdf_y_variable_name, netcdf_y_transformation, netcdf_type, netcdf_convention.

section.para:
Finally, the action routine PNETCDF is called without any parameters. Note that in the above example, most of the parameters are not required as their default values are the same. See
for the complete list of parameters and their defaults.
Note that Magics does not currently produce an automatic title for NetCDF data - an appropriate title should be supplied by the user.

section.para: All input data for graph plotting are passed to Magics via arrays. The parameter GRAPH_TYPE is used to describe the type of graph required. Valid values are CURVE (default), BAR and AREA.
When set to CURVE, two one-dimensional arrays are used to pass the data describing the curve, e.g.
